occurrences.line_text: In which that manly person late did fade,
To rest thy wearie person, in the shadow coole.
Well knew they both his person, sith of late
The trespasse still doth liue, albe the person die.
Flesh without bloud, a person without spright,
A iolly person, and of comely vew;
And what so else his person most may vaunt?
Portly his person was, and much increast
Whose shape or person yet I neuer saw,
The rest vpon her person gaue attendance great.
Least saluage beastes her person haue despoyld:
Without respect of person or of port,
His person to emperill so in fight.
For they so like in person did appeare,
Her person late in perill, did remaine,
That vnto euery person knew her part;
Vppon her person for her sure defence,
And in her person cunningly did shade
And her proud person low prostrated on the plaine.
Her person, and her sacred selfe to slay:
Then vp arose a person of deepe reach,
He now t'abhorre and loath her person had procured.
And without sword his person to defend.
Some goodly person, and of gentle race,
That all men did her person much admire,
And eeke of person huge and hideous,
But rends without regard of person or of time.
Wise, warlike, personable, curteous, and kind.
With goodly grace and comely personage,
Seemd to haue beene a goodly personage,
And with selfe-loued personage deceiu'd,
Downe to the ground, a comely personage,
His goodly reason, and graue personage,
A comely personage of stature tall,
The Damzell well did vew his personage,
In that foule plight a comely personage,
Her goodly personage and glorious hew,
Of some Theatre, a graue personage,
Which to thy noble personage I beare,
As might become a Squire so great persons to greet.
The fift had charge sicke persons to attend,
And antique praises vnto present persons fit.
Of persons flockt, whose names is hard to read:
Of all those persons, which she saw without:
And eke of priuate persons many moe,
And shrowd their persons from that stormie stowre.
And by his persons secret seemlyhed
With which she guiltlesse persons may accuse,
Of our like persons eath to be disguiz'd,
How that three warlike persons did appeare,
Many graue persons, that against her pled;
And all such persons, as did late maintayne
They knew them selues, and both their persons rad:
And all such persons, as he earst did wrong,
Feele my heart perst with so great agonie,
That with their force they perst both plate and maile,
And through his soule like poysned arrow perst,
That could haue perst the hearts of Tigres & of Beares.
By the great persue, which she there perceau'd,
Her to perswade, that stubborne fort to yilde:
Perswade vs die, to stint all further strife:
And Orcus tame, whom nothing can perswade,
And hasting towards him gan faire perswade,
Where him to sleepe she gently would perswade,
Ah, but if reason faire might you perswade,
And sacred Peace shall louingly perswade
Her Sea-god syre she dearely did perswade,
Tho gan he her perswade, to leaue that lewd
Leaue nought vnpromist, that may him perswade,
But by no meanes could her thereto perswade:
So can they both them selues full eath perswade
He gan with guilefull words her to perswade,
The which did her co[m]maund, without needing perswade.
To which he easily did them perswade.
Him otherwise perswade, all that she might;
Which gaue him hope, and did him halfe perswade,
She hardly yet perswaded was to stay,
That her perswaded to disclose the breach,
Perswaded him to ceasse, and her Lord to relent.
Thus she at length perswaded him to rise,
Stroue to appease him, and perswaded long:
Yet would he not perswaded be for ought,
With gentle words perswading them to friendly peace.
But faire Cambina with perswasions myld,
Yet he with strong perswasions her asswaged,
Her to bethinke of, that mote to her selfe pertaine.
Threatning to chastize me, as doth t'a chyld pertaine.
That liues, pertaines in charge particulare,
To you that ornament of hers pertaines,
But this to you, ï¿½ Britons, most pertaines,
Her gentle Squire through her displeasure did pertake.
Therefore since now to thee perteines the same,
Then stubborne perturbation, to the same;
Who euer heard of th'Indian Peru?
Or th'Indian Peru he were, she thought
Now like a Ram, faire Helle to peruart,
That ioyd in happy peace, till fates peruerse
Against these pesants, which haue me opprest,
The heate whereof, and harmefull pestilence
And them with plagues and murrins pestilent
The bird, that warned Peter of his fall,
The Sunnes bright wayne to Phaetons decay,
So many moe, as there be phantasies
That hight Phantastes by his nature trew;
And straunge phantomes doth let vs oft forsee,
Wherein th'ï¿½gyptian Phao long did lurke
Fairest Pherusa, Phao lilly white,
Slow Peneus, and tempestuous Phasides,
Compar'd to her, that shone as Phebes light,
For which Dan Phebus selfe cannot a salue prouide.
Whose goodly light then Phebus lampe doth shine more cleare?
Deliuers Phedon, and therefore
Phedon I hight (quoth he) and do aduaunce
Fairest Pherusa, Phao lilly white,
Phidias did make in Paphos Isle of yore,
My friend, hight Philemon, I did partake
Confest, how Philemon her wrought to chaunge her weede.
To Philemon, false faytour Philemon
To Philemon, false faytour Philemon
When for to compasse Philliras hard loue,
Witnesse the father of Philosophie,
Pourd out his life, and last Philosophy
All artes, all science, all Philosophy,
Or noursle vp in lore of learn'd Philosophy.
And faire Philotime she rightly hight,
That further mayd, hight Philtera the faire,
But now when Philtra saw my lands decay,
Both Amidas and Philtra were displeased:
Which Phison and Euphrates floweth by,
And come to fiery flood of Phlegeton,
Acrates sonne of Phlegeton and Iarre;
But Phlegeton is sonne of Herebus and Night;
In flaming Phlegeton does not so felly roste.
Firebrand of hell first tynd in Phlegeton,
By thundring Ioue in the Phlegrean plaine.
And triumphes of PhlegrÃ¦an Ioue he wrote,
Which with a teeme of scaly Phocas bound
Great Belus, Phoeax, and Agenor best;
The cause was this: one day when Phoebe fayre
Now hath faire Phoebe with her siluer face
But Phoebe therewith sore was angered,
Dame Phoebe to a Nymph her babe betooke,
Like Phoebus lampe throughout the world doth shine,
When ruddy Phoebus gins to welke in west,
Had warned once, that Phoebus fiery carre
For golden Phoebus now ymounted hie,
Exceeding shone, like Phoebus fairest childe,
And Phoebus fresh, as bridegrome to his mate,
That Phoebus chearefull face durst neuer vew,
To runne her timely race, whilst Phoebus pure
And Phoebus flying so most shamefull sight,
Like glauncing light of Phoebus brightest ray;
That Phoebus golden face it did attaint,
Faire ympe of Phoebus, and his aged bride,
Now gan the golden Phoebus for to steepe
Scarsely had Phoebus in the glooming East
Like Phoebus face adornd with sunny rayes,
And now faire Phoebus gan decline in hast
By Phoebus doome, the wisest thought aliue,
Or rather worthy of great Phoebus rote,
Such as Laomedon of Phoebus race did breed.
Faire Daphne Phoebus hart with loue did gore;
Lookt foorth, as Phoebus face out of the east,
Daughter of Phoebus and of Memorie,
Belphoebe was her name, as faire as Phoebus sunne.
And Phoebus with faire beames did her adorne,
That nether Phoebus beams could through the[m] throng,
Fresh Hyacinthus, Phoebus paramoure,
The morow next, so soone as Phoebus Lamp
Till drouping Phoebus gan to hide his golden hed.
And thou, faire Phoebus, in thy colours bright
Of th'Oceans seede, but Ioues and Phoebus kinde;
Mounted in Phoebus charet fierie bright,
Now when as Phoebus with his fiery waine
That was the wanton Phoedria, which late
Phoenix, and Aon, and Pelasgus old,
And Pholoe fowle, when her to this he doth compaire.
Phorcys, the father of that fatall brood,
Phrixus and Helle from their stepdames feares,
On Phrygian Paris by Plexippus brooke,
O foolish Physick, and vnfruitfull paine,
Of PhÃ¦dria (for so my name is red)
Of PhÃ¦dria, thine owne fellow seruaunt;
Accompanyde with PhÃ¦dria the faire,
Still as he stood, faire PhÃ¦dria, that beheld
In PhÃ¦drias flit barke ouer that perlous shard.
Bene choisely picked out from all the rest,
A place pickt out by choice of best aliue,
Vnto the Prince of Picteland bordering nere,
Then gan the Hunnes and Picts inuade this land,
Those spoilefull Picts, and swarming Easterlings,
For dread of whom, and for those Picts annoyes,
Against the Picts, that swarmed ouer all,
Of famous Wisards, and with picturals
And his deare hart the picture gan adore,
Beare ye the picture of that Ladies head?
Faire Sir (said he) if in that picture dead
The glorious picture vanisheth away,
The picture of his punishment might see,
Your selfe you couet to see pictured,
In which a gracious seruant pictured
Next vnto him was Neptune pictured,
Androgeus and Tenantius, pictures of his might.
In picturing the parts of beautie daint,
Through vainely crossed shield he quite did pierce,
Which passing through the eares, would pierce the hart,
But it would pierce or cleaue, where so it came;
And more to make the[m] pierce & wound more deepe,
And pierced to the skin, but bit no more,
Into his throate and life it pierced quight,
Or thrild with point of thorough piercing paine;
That the cold steele through piercing, did deuowre
And through his shoulder pierst; wherwith to grou[n]d
And pierst into her wombe, where they embayd
Her hart was pierst with pittie at the sight,
Pierst through his beuer quite into his brow,
Past through his shield, & pierst through either syde,
And by my wretched louers side me pight,
But in the same a little grate was pight,
As if in Adamant rocke it had bene pight.
But hong still on the shield, as it at first was pight.
And kist the ground, whereon his foot was pight;
Therein an hundred raunges weren pight,
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
In whose enclosed shadow there was pight
Or on the marble Pillour, that is pight
And here and there were pleasant arbors pight,
Is wandred farre from where it first was pight,
And in the same are many trap fals pight,
The earth was in the middle centre pight,
Causd his pauilion to be richly pight
Where was a rich Pauilion ready pight,
She caused her Pauilion be pight;
For on his head vnhappily he pight,
For he was strong and mightily stiffe pight,
And therein left the pike head of his speare.
Had riuen many a brest with pikehead square;
And Lindus that his pikes doth most commend,
I Pilate am the falsest Iudge, alas,
Against the fiue great Bulwarkes of that pile,
Like to a rancke of piles, that pitched are awry.
Then gan the Pilgrim thus, I chaunst this day,
But that false Pilgrim, which that leasing told,
At last resoluing, like a pilgrim pore,
A silly Pilgrim driuen to distresse,
Then peaceably thy painefull pilgrimage
To walke this way in Pilgrims poore estate.
As if this to adorne, she all the rest did pill.
Of nightly stelths and pillage seuerall,
And brought the pillage home, whence none could get it out.
And in the midst thereof a piller placed;
Vpon an hundred marble pillors round
And euery pillour decked was full deare
Of euery pillour and of euery post;
Or on the marble Pillour, that is pight
Vnto a brasen pillour, by the which she stands.
And that great brasen pillour broke in peeces small.
Then preacing to the pillour I repeated
That seem'd a marble pillour it could bow:
Like two faire marble pillours they were seene,
Many great golden pillours did vpbeare
Like mightie pillours, this fraile life of man,
Distaines the pillours, and the holy grownd,
Though all the pillours of the one were guilt,
On stately pillours, fram'd after the Doricke guize.
Borne vppon stately pillours, all dispred
And pillow was my helmet faire displayd:
The cold earth was his couch, the hard steele his pillow.
Must be their bed, their pillow was vnsowed,
Her paps, which like white silken pillowes were,
Withouten oare or Pilot it to guide,
As Pilot well expert in perilous waue,
Loue my lewd Pilot hath a restlesse mind
Couered with cloudes, her Pilot hath dismayd;
Which pols and pils the poore in piteous wize;
And sternly lookes at him, who not a pin
Only she turn'd a pin, and by and by
To pluck it out with pincers firie whot,
A paire of Pincers in his hand he had,
With which he pinched people to the hart,
Pinckt vpon gold, and paled part per part,
With thornes together pind and patched was,
And pensiue sorrow pind and wore away,
Sith her whylome vpon high Pindus hill,
The sayling Pine, the Cedar proud and tall,
His raw-bone cheekes through penurie and pine,
Whiles thus thy Britons do in languour pine,
With hatefull thoughts to languish and to pine,
Or by some deadly chaunce be done to pine,
His pined corse, him scarse to light could beare,
That like a pined ghost he soone appeares.
And eke the pennes, that did his pineons bynd,
His newly budded pineons to assay,
How oft do they with golden pineons, cleaue
And with her pineons cleaues the liquid firmament.
Nor so did Biblis spend her pining hart,
With both his hands behinde him pinnoed hard,
His mery oaten pipe, but shund th'vnlucky ground.
Till by a conduit pipe it thence were brought:
His weasand pipe it through his gorget cleft:
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
Of a shrill pipe he playing heard on hight,
That made him pipe so merrily, as neuer none.
She made me often pipe and now to pipe apace.
She made me often pipe and now to pipe apace.
Which piped there vnto that merry rout:
That iolly shepheard, which there piped, was
And all the way their merry pipes they sound,
And in the midst a Shepheard piping he did see.
Through the AEgaean seas from Pirates vew,
Stout Theseus, and Pirithous his feare;
And eke that ample Pit, yet farre renownd,
Into some pit, where she him heares complaine,
An hundred times about the pit side fares,
Her twyfold Teme, of which two blacke as pitch,
Aboue his wonted pitch, with countenance fell,
Till it the pitch of highest prayse exceeds:
And far aboue thy forces pitch to sore.
From pitch of higher place, vnto this low degree.
Like to a rancke of piles, that pitched are awry.
There to be pitched on the open plaine;
With suddaine feare her pitcher downe she threw,
And in a foule blacke pitchie mantle clad,
He pitcht vpon a pole on high ordayned;
With which his locks, as blacke as pitchy night,
Therewith a piteous yelling voyce was heard,
Her piteous words might not abate his rage,
And piteous plaints she filleth his dull eares,
O heare, how piteous he to you for ayd does call.
That hardest heart would bleede, to heare their piteous mone.
These piteous plaints and dolours did resound;
Which piteous spectacle, approuing trew
With piteous mone his percing speach gan paint;
Wringing her hands, and making piteous mone;
Of fowles and beastes he made the piteous prayes,
She ouerhent, nought moued with her piteous looke.
That made his spright to grone full piteous:
A piteous spectacle did represent,
With sighes, and sobs, and plaints, & piteous griefe,
She made so piteous mone and deare wayment,
She was empassiond at that piteous act,
Full many piteous stories doe remaine,
But none more piteous euer was ytold,
They which that piteous spectacle beheld,
Led with that wofull Ladies piteous crying,
And there a piteous ditty new deuiz'd,
But most was moued at the piteous vew
Will yeeld, but when my piteous plaints he heares,
Which pols and pils the poore in piteous wize;
Vnmou'd with praiers, or with piteous thought,
Does make her selfe misfortunes piteous pray.
Who all that piteous storie, which befell
And sent them home to tell a piteous tale,
To heare the piteous beast pleading her plaintiffe cause.
There then a piteous slaughter did begin:
Come home to her in piteous wretchednesse,
With piteous ruth of her so wretched plight,
Much was he moued with her piteous plight,
Who seeing him from farre, with piteous sound
That piteous spoile by so iniurious theft.
And made such piteous mourning therewithall,
Weeping to him in vaine, and making piteous woe.
Drawne with that Ladies loud and piteous shright,
And all the woods with piteous plaints did fill,
In piteous languor, since ye hither came,
And now triumphest in the piteous spoile
That all her piteous plaint they did refuse,
As her to leaue in such a piteous plight.
Her mournefull notes full piteously did frame,
Great sorts of louers piteously complayning,
That piteously complaind her carefull grieffe,
His wofull Ladie, piteously complayning
And beat her breast, and piteously her selfe torment.
Vnto her prayers piteously enclynd,
Like an old Oke whose pith and sap is seare,
Of ruefull pitie, and impatient smart,
For pitie that ye want a fellow for your ayd.
That those, whom she to pitie had allured,
Percing his hart with pities point did thrill;
Pitifull spectacle, as euer eye did view.
Him stayd from yielding pitifull redresse;
Behold, Sir, how your pitifull complaint
And his sad Ladie left in pitifull affright.
And backe retire, all scorcht and pitifully brent.
That both their speares with pitilesse remorse,
And crying Mercy lowd, his pitious hands gan reare.
His sad dull eyes deepe sunck in hollow pits,
Wringing her hands in wemens pitteous wise,
The pitteous maiden carefull comfortlesse,
Who when they heard that pitteous strained voice,
Yet might her pitteous hart be seene to pant and quake.
The pitteous pray of his fierce crueltie haue bin.
At her so pitteous cry was much amoou'd
When of his pitteous tale he end did make;
Crying with pitteous voice, and count'nance wan;
Your cruell eyes endure so pitteous sight,
That with their pitteous cryes, and yelling shrights,
How euer, sure I rew his pitteous plight.
And pitteous Elidure put in his sted;
And the rich wares to saue from pitteous spoyle,
In mischiefe, was much moued at so pitteous sight.
The whiles the pitteous Ladie vp did ryse,
He bound that pitteous Lady prisoner, now relest,
Would make to melt, or pitteously appall;
Yet she with pitthy words and counsell sad,
When such I see, that all for pittie I could die.
Him prickt, in pittie of my sad estate:
With pittie calmd, downe fell his angry mood.
But full great pittie, that so faire a mould
Yet pittie in her hart was neuer proued
And gin to pittie her vnhappie state,
Great pittie is to see you thus dismaid,
Your yron brestes, or pittie could find place,
Then pittie, he in hast approched to the shore.
That certes it great pittie was to see
Great pittie sure, that ye be so forlorne
Ne euer pittie may relent his malice hard.
Yet pittie often did the gods relent,
Her hart was pierst with pittie at the sight,
That I with teares full oft doe pittie it,
And griefull pittie priuately bemone.
Alas for pittie that so faire a crew,
That pittie is to heare the perils, which she tride.
Ne care he had, ne pittie of the pray,
Bvt ah for pittie that I haue thus long
To Artegall, through pittie of his causelesse smart.
First there came Pittie, with full tender hart,
And being moou'd with pittie of my plight,
Did taste of pittie, neither gentlesse knew,
Did counterfeit kind pittie, where was none:
And seeing them, for tender pittie wept:
And seeing there, that did him pittie sore,
She knew him not, but pittied much his case,
Well she it markt, and pittied the more,
The foolish man, that pitties all this while
That euen to thinke thereof, it inly pitties mee.
Great pleasure mixt with pittifull regard,
Whiles they his pittifull aduentures heard,
Pittifull spectacle of deadly smart,
With percing words, and pittifull implore,
Who when those pittifull outcries he heard,
Empierced was with pittifull regard,
Wayling, and raysing pittifull vprore,
And pittifull complaints, which there she made,
Of one, that wayld and pittifull[y] wept,
For which it loudly cald, and pittifully cryde.
And with most cruell hand him murdred pittilesse.
Guyon broke downe, with rigour pittilesse;
Crauing of you in pitty of my state,
Are wonne with pitty and vnwonted ruth,
That it would pitty any liuing eie.
Of pitty deare his hart was thrilled sore,
For pitty of his paine and anguish sore;
That I note, whether prayse, or pitty more:
And naked brest, in pitty of their harmes,
That we may pitty such vnhappy bale,
Ne let thy stout hart melt in pitty vayne:
But Ã´; great pitty, that no lenger time
Who stird with pitty of the stressed plight
Through foolish pitty, then her guilefull bayt
Pitty our plaint, and yield vs meet reliefe.
The point of pitty perced through her tender hart.
That pitty did the Virgins hart of patience rob.
For nothing so much pitty doth implore,
Thy ruefull plight I pitty as mine owne.
And pitty much his plight, that liu'd like outcast thrall.
Was toucht with soft remorse and pitty rare;
Withouten pitty of her goodly hew,
Yet for no pitty would he change the course
Ne would he spare for pitty, nor refraine for feare.
Neither of other taking pitty nor remorse.
For pitty of his Dame, whom she saw so diseased.
That pitty craues, as he of woman was yborne.
But most for pitty of his dearest Dame,
For pitty so to see him ouerset.
That they to pitty turnd their former rage,
Receiued had, and prayd to pitty his ill plight.
Ne ought that foole for pitty did him spare,
Without regard of pitty or of awe.
To pitty him that list to play the foole:
And pitty her sad plight, so chang'd from pleasaunt hew.
For passing ioy, which did all into pitty melt.
For Cadwan pittying his peoples ill,
As pittying to see her waile and weepe;
But gazed on their harmes, not pittying their estate.
Moued with pity of her plenteous teares.
Whom pitying to heare so sore complaine,
The danger hid, the place vnknowne and wilde,
Yea but (quoth she) the perill of this place
The fearefull Dwarfe:) this is no place for liuing men.
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
And shall you well reward to shew the place,
Then was she faire alone, when none was faire in place.
And made a sunshine in the shadie place;
To weet, if dwelling place were nigh at hand;
Was for to seeke aduenture in strange place,
Deare Sir, what euer that thou be in place:
Both day and night, of each degree and place,
Which with their presence faire, the place much beautifide.
Suddein vpriseth from her stately place
